metadata.title: Syndemic frameworks to understand the effects of COVID-19 on commercial driver stress, health, and safety

body_text.text: 1 ABSTRACT 1 Introduction 2 U.S. commercial drivers are entrenched in a stressogenic profession, and exposures to endemic 3 chronic stressors shape drivers' behavioral and psychosocial responses and induce profound 4 health and safety disparities. To gain a complete understanding of how the COVID-19 pandemic 5 will affect commercial driver stress, health, and safety over time, and to mitigate these impacts, 6 research and prevention efforts must be grounded in theoretical perspectives that contextualize 7 these impacts within the chronic stressors already endemic to profession, the historical and 8 ongoing forces that have induced them, and the potentially reinforcing nature of the resulting 9 afflictions.

Extant literature reveals how an array of macro-level changes has shaped downstream trucking 12 industry policies, resulting in stressogenic work organization and workplace characteristics. 13 Emerging evidence suggests that the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbates existing stressors and 14 introduces novel stressors, with potentially exacerbatory impacts on health and safety disparities.

As COVID-19 exerts an array of multi-level stressors on commercial drivers, syndemic 17 frameworks can provide the appropriate theoretical lens to guide research and prevention. 18 Syndemic frameworks can provide the grounding to allow foregoing commercial driver 19 research to transcend the limitations of prevailing research frameworks by contextualizing 20 COVID-19 stressors holistically within the complex system of endemic chronic stressors and 21 interrelated health and safety afflictions. Syndemic-informed prevention efforts can then be 22 implemented that simultaneously tackle multiple afflictions and the macro-level forces that result 23 in the emergence of commercial drivers' health and safety disparities over time.

The impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on commercial drivers cannot be adequately understood 26 or acted upon in isolation from the endemic chronic stressors and interrelated health and safety 27 disparities that characterize the profession. However, to 45 gain a complete understanding of how the COVID-19 pandemic will affect commercial driver 46 stress, health, and safety over time -and to be able to ascertain how to best take action to 47 mitigate these impacts -research and prevention efforts must be grounded in theoretical 48 perspectives that contextualize these impacts within the chronic stressors already endemic to 49 profession, the historical and ongoing forces that have induced them, and the potentially 50 reinforcing nature of the resulting afflictions. Thus, using U.S. long-haul truck drivers as an 51 illustrative example, we advocate for using syndemic frameworks to guide research and 52 prevention regarding the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on commercial driver stress, health, 53 and safety. home for weeks at a time, which effectively makes their worksites their "homes" for prolonged 77 periods of time. 12 As a result, drivers are particularly dependent on the amenities available in 78 these locales; however, these environments are notorious for lacking medical services or 79 5 opportunities for physical activity and healthy eating. 2, 11, 13 The mandatory prolonged periods 80 away from family and friends, exacerbated by scheduling and financial pressures, lead to chronic 81 social isolation 3,11,14 that is compounded by a pervasive lack of respect for LHTD that is manifest 82 through their numerous daily interactions with general public and, due to inherent job 83 requirements to act as a boundary spanner, customers, dispatchers, and even the government. 11
These multi-level chronic stressors often induce detrimental behavioral and psychosocial 85 responses by LHTD and significantly contribute to their excessive health and safety disparities.

As a result, the nearly 36 two million U.S. long-haul truck drivers (LHTD) 1 currently find themselves entrenched in an 37 increasingly stressogenic 2 profession due to the downstream, interacting, dynamic, and evolving 38 impacts of such macro-level changes. Exposures to the chronic stressors that are now endemic 39 within the long-haul trucking profession shape drivers' behavioral and psychosocial responses 3 40 and induce health and safety disparities that are among the worst of any occupation. 1,4,5 41 Although empirical research is not yet available regarding the impacts on coronavirus 42 2019 (COVID-19) on commercial driver stress, health and safety, emerging evidence suggests 43

FIGREF1.text: Multi-Level Forces and Commercial Drivers' Stress, Health, and Safety56 4 An array of macro-level changes has increased chronic stress exposures among LHTD. 57 Macroeconomic forces related to declines in manufacturing wages, which are strongly correlated 58 with truck driver wages, have eroded earnings over time. 7 Federal policy changes have 59 generated downstream impacts on the work organization of LHTD -in particular, the passage of 60 the Motor Carrier Act of 1980, which deregulated the trucking industry 8 and led to reduced 61 LHTD union presence and protections and intense trucking industry competition, resulting in 62 declines in wages and working conditions. 7 Even federal policies intended to protect roadway 63 safety have had counterintuitive impacts that have increased LHTD stress. For example, federal 64 hours-of-service (HOS) laws create a regulatory environment where drivers are subject to the 65 intense competitive pressures in the current trucking industry and yet are liable for HOS 66 violations as they try to meet these demands. 7 67 These macro-level forces have shaped downstream trucking company policies and 68 practices, resulting in numerous stressogenic work organization characteristics and workplace 69 experiences for LHTD. The intense competition ushered in by deregulation has resulted in 70 rigorous and erratic work schedules, often characterized by long work hours and shift work. 2,9 71 "By-the-mile" pay, the most common form of LHTD compensation, is illustrative of 72 competition-driven wage declines and only provides drivers with income when their vehicles are 73 moving and does not fairly compensate for non-driving tasks that constitute a significant portion 74 of their working time. 8,10,11 Other trucking industry-relevant corporate policies also induce 75 LHTD chronic stress. However, 100 emerging anecdotal evidence affords us clues into key COVID-19 stressors and their plausible 101 consequences. These stressors can be broadly categorized as either exacerbatory or novel. 102 6 Several aspects of the COVID-19 pandemic can exacerbate endemic chronic stressors. 103 Drivers are under immense pressure from to maintain critical supply chains and accommodate 104 demand surges for consumer and healthcare goods, 6 and these pressures have been exacerbated 105 by concerns about travel restrictions 26,27 and enabled by the relaxation of HOS rules for the 106 transportation of essential goods. 28 However, these pressures are now combined with freight 107 volatility, as overall trucking volumes are expected to slow down and demands for other goods, 108 such as those related to manufacturing, have already declined. 26,29 Impending declines in freight 109 volumes are expected to threaten drivers' wages and potentially their livelihoods. 26 Further, as 110 the result of physical distancing mandates, worksite amenities have become even more sparse; as 111 a result, many drivers have struggled with finding meals, safe parking, restrooms, and 112 showers. 30,31 113 The COVID-19 pandemic also presents an array of novel stressors for LHTD. One new 114 source of stress is worrying about getting sick from COVID-19, which is compounded due to the 115 fact that they may fall ill thousands of miles from home and without any practical means for 116 testing, treatment, or quarantine. 6,31,32 Drivers expose themselves to infection as they move in 117 and out of areas with outbreaks, 32 and as they interact with various social contacts they pose 118 acquisition and transmission risks to themselves and others. 6,33 These worries are made worse by 119 the absence of personal protective equipment available to them, 32,34 as well as a lack of corporate 120 policies to protect them from infection, such as workplace physical distancing protocols and 121 open and prompt communication about possible workplace infection cases. 34 122 The potential consequences that these COVID-19 stressors pose to LHTD health and 123 safety are numerous. One consequence may be strains on supply chains due to labor 124 fluctuations. The trucking industry was experiencing a labor shortage before the onset of the 125 7 COVID-19 pandemic, 35 and the lack of PPE or other policies to prevent LHTD infection may 126 result in walk-outs, absenteeism, and leave. 34 Drivers may leave the profession altogether due to 127 increased levels of burnout or alienation as the result of these stressors. 11,36 Supply chain strains 128 may create greater pressures on the remaining labor pool to fulfill demand surges, resulting in a 129 vicious cycle of even greater LHTD chronic stress. FIGREF4.text: However, prevailing research frameworks are grounded in reductionist and linear assumptions of 145 cause and effect 47 and pursue identifiable risk factors.48,49  This focus on variable isolation 47 to 146 tease apart the influence of individual risk factors is antithetical to understanding the dynamic, 147 multi-level, and interacting array of stressors and downstream consequences that altogether 148 8 constitute a complex system. Further, these frameworks tend to overlook both the macro-level 149 forces that lead to the clustering of adverse outcomes in populations and the interrelated and150 potentially reinforcing nature of these outcomes. 49 This means that the consequences of the 151 COVID-19 pandemic for LHTD cannot be adequately understood -or acted upon -in isolation 152 from the inherently stressogenic context of the profession, the historical and ongoing forces that 153 have induced the chronic stressors and health and safety disparities endemic to the profession, 154 and the potentially reinforcing nature of these afflictions. Instead, commercial driver COVID-19 155 research and prevention needs theoretical frameworks that contextualize COVID-19 stressors 156 holistically within the complex system of endemic chronic stressors and interrelated health and 157 safety outcomes. 158 In our view, syndemic frameworks can provide the appropriate theoretical lens to guide 159 commercial driver COVID-19 research and prevention. The term 'syndemic' is defined as the 160 clustering, due to sociostructural forces, of two or more interacting and exacerbatory afflictions 161 within a population. 49 The dual emphasis of syndemic frameworks on the clustering of health 162 and safety within populations due to macro-level forces and on the reinforcing nature of these 163 afflictions can provide the grounding to allow foregoing COVID-19 commercial driver research 164 to transcend the limitations of prevailing research frameworks. 49,50 This understanding can then 165 embody the emergence of interrelated health and safety afflictions due to the endemic 166 stressogenic nature of long-haul trucking, how they are continually shaped by the dynamic 167 macro-level policies and forces that have unfolded over time, and how these afflictions may 168 perpetuate extant disparities and shape morbidity/mortality vulnerabilities. 49 In the case of 169 COVID-19, those macro-level policies and forces that perpetuate disparities can be expected to 170 similarly induce detrimental outcomes to novel pandemic stressors, along with a worsening of 9 related endemic stressors and corresponding stress responses. The consequences can be 172 expected to synergistically interact with existing disparities and unfold across heterogeneous 173 timeframes -for example, short timeframes for consequences associated with acute COVID-19 174infection and full recovery (e.g., temporary loss of labor supply), and longer timeframes for 175 consequences associated with inadequate trucking company policies to protect workers from 176 COVID-19 infection (e.g., workforce burnout and alienation).

FIGREF5.text: As the complete picture of the impacts of COVID-19 on commercial drivers' stress,178    health, and safety emerges through research grounded in syndemic frameworks, prevention 179 efforts could then be implemented that simultaneously tackle multiple afflictions and the macro-180 level forces that resulted in the emergence of commercial drivers' health and safety disparities 181 over time. In contrast to the limitations of individual-focused, single-component or multi-182 component interventions 49,51 that are most commonplace and most likely to be characteristic of 183 foregoing COVID-19 programming, syndemic frameworks inherently inform large-scale public 184 policy interventions that target macro-level drivers of disparities within populations, while also 185 incorporating the presence of interrelated afflictions and vulnerabilities. 49 As a result, these 186 prevention efforts would constitute holistic multi-level interventions that both modify the macro-187 level forces that have led to the clustering of disparities and also address and treat health and 188 safety vulnerabilities and outcomes at the driver-level. changes have fundamentally altered the structure and organization of the 192 work and workplaces of U.S. commercial drivers. Due to the impacts of these changes, U.S. 193 LHTD are entrenched in a stressogenic profession, where endemic chronic stressors shape 194 10 drivers' behavioral and psychosocial responses and contribute significantly to profound health 195 and safety disparities. The impacts of the current COVID-19 pandemic cannot be adequately 196 understood or acted upon in isolation from the inherently stressogenic context of the profession.
